section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Barbara Bottner and illustrated by Chris Sheban
section-block.rac_book_summary: A little girl with a cold learns how to take care of herself when she is not feeling well.

section-block.rac_body-text: Ask children if they have ever had a cold. Invite them to describe what it was like to have a cold and what they did to get better.
Have children act out as they chant: “Sniff, shiver, cough, AaaCHOO!/Stay warm, take a nap [snore] and send that cold away from you!”

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read a book called What a Cold Needs written by Barbara Bottner and illustrated by Chris Sheban.
Scout loves reading books about ways that he can feel better when he has a cold.

section.rac_guiding-question_blue: I would like you to think about this question as we read. We will talk about it later. Ready?
What could you do when you have a cold?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts. Use Equity Sticks to help choose children to respond to questions.
Pause and ask children to come to the book and identify some upper- and lowercase letters.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How do you think the girl in the picture feels? How can you tell?
What is the girl doing? Why do you think she likes to do this when she has a cold?
pages 8–9
Staying warm helps you get better faster when you have a cold.
Why do you think the girl is putting on warm socks?
pages 10–11
What things on these two pages show that people are taking care of the girl?

Sometimes people like to be alone when they’re not feeling well. Sometimes it is good to tell people what you need. Do you think the girl told her parents she needed some time alone? How can you tell?
What is happening in this picture? Does the girl like it? How can you tell?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What could you do when you have a cold?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Then, use Equity Sticks to help choose 2–3 children to share their responses.
Possible responses:
Write and read aloud short sentences about taking care of yourself when you have a cold.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Could you take a nap or go for a run when you have a cold?
I could take a n___ (nap) when I have a cold.
I could take a nap when I have a cold.
Why is it important to take a nap when you have a cold?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Keep in mind that cultures differ in how they conceptualize and treat the common cold and other illnesses. As you read this week’s book aloud, be mindful of the fact that the treatments suggested in the book may not necessarily be used in some of your students’ families. Encourage children to share their own experiences.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Problem Solving
section-block.rac_body-text: Tell children that problem solving means trying to find a way to fix a problem, or something that is not going well. Explain that sometimes they will be able to solve their problems on their own, but other times they may need to ask an adult for help. Invite children to share examples of problems that they have had and how they solved them. (MB)

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to think about how the girl in the book What a Cold Needs uses the problem-solving Mind Builder.
This story is about a problem that many children have in real life. Clifford loves thinking about how to solve problems!

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread the book and notice the problem solving Mind Builder in action.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What is the girl doing to help herself feel better? How does the picture help you tell that she is feeling comfy? (MB)
Sometimes you may need an adult to help you solve a problem. (MB)
Who helps the girl in the story? How do they help her?
Sometimes medicine can help when you are feeling sick, but it is not safe to take medicine unless an adult gives it to you. How can you take medicine safely?
The girl is feeling better. She is running around now.
The word around has more than one meaning. It may mean going in a circle, or it may mean going in all different directions.
At the end of the story, the girl’s dad has a cold. How could he solve this problem? How are the girl and the dog helping him solve it? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Challenge children to use their problem-solving skills as they go on a treasure hunt around the classroom or playground. Set up 5–10 clues in various locations. Each clue should lead to the next clue. Have children work together in teams to complete the treasure hunt.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about taking care of themselves.
As you write down their ideas, ask children what other words you could use instead of a particular verb or adjective.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Preschoolers learn problem-solving skills from frequent experience solving problems that arise in their day-to-day life. Allow them to find their own solutions to their problems whenever possible. Help them by asking open-ended questions (e.g., “What could you do to solve that problem?”), but do not solve their problems for them. (Miller and Poole, 2019)

section-block.rac_body-text: Help children make connections between the book and their own lives.
Play “Head, Shoulders, Knees, and Toes” with children. Ask them to share which body parts in the song are most affected by a cold.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread What a Cold Needs. This book has words by Barbara Bottner and pictures by Chris Sheban.
Scout loves What a Cold Needs, because it gives great tips about what to do when you have a cold!
I want you to think about this question as we reread. We will talk about it later:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What can you do to feel better when you have a cold?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose students to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The girl can hear birds chirping outside. How do you think being near the window helps her feel comfortable while she naps?
Family members, including the girl’s grandpa, help the girl feel better.
How can others help you when you are sick?
Music is playing while the girl sleeps. Does music make it harder or easier for you to sleep? Does that change when you are sick?
The girl plays quietly with her dog. Do you like to have a pet or family member near when you don’t feel well? Why or why not?
Look at these four pictures of the girl. Do you think she feels better in the last picture than in the first one? Why do you think that?
Did you make any connections between what the girl did when she had a cold and what you would do? Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What can you do to feel better when you have a cold?
Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
section.rac_body-text: Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: You can let others take good care of you.
You can have pets or family members nearby.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen as you write together about taking care of yourself. Invite children to add letters or end punctuation.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Can having a pet near help you feel better or worse when you have a cold?
Having a pet n_____ (near) can help you feel better.
Having a pet near can help you feel better.
Why do you think it helps to rest when you have a cold?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: All language learners need repeated exposures to words to gain a deeper understanding of what they mean and how they are used. Presenting vocabulary in context is an especially effective way for children to gain these exposures, because they lea rn to form associations between words.

section-block.rac_body-text: Have children discuss ways they can care for themselves when they are healthy. Are those ways different from what they do when they are sick?
Sing to the tune of “The More We Get Together.” “If we wash our hands more often, more often, more often . . . the healthier we will be.”

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Keep Your Hands Clean. It is an informational text in the form of a poster.
Scout loves to look at informational posters. They give great information!
What a Cold Needs and Keep Your Hands Clean are both about how we can take care of ourselves. Let’s find some connections between the two.
As we read this week’s Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:
How can we stay healthy?

section.rac_body-text: Read-aloud the teacher text from the Big Chart and teach the song. Then use these prompts to discuss the child-facing poster together.
Use Equity Sticks to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Which picture shows the first thing we do when we wash our hands?
What do we do next? Who can point to the picture showing that?
Which picture shows how to scrub our hands with soap? Why should we scrub our hands with soap when we have a cold?
We rinse our hands with water after we scrub them. Which picture shows that?
What is the last thing we do after we wash our hands? Who can find the picture that shows that?

section.rac_body-text: Have children show how they would scrub and rinse their hands. Tell them to imagine their hands are already wet and soapy, and then to listen and follow your directions:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: First, scrub your hands while we sing the song on the Big Chart. Don’t stop until the singing stops!Second, pretend to rinse your hands. What comes next?

section.rac_body-text: Provide a writing prompt about taking care of yourself. Give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt. Encourage children to use new words in their responses.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Young children have a tremendous ability to develop habits that will benefit them for life. Focusing on how to practice self-care—not only when they are sick but also when they are well—can help them establish good health habits that will stay with them always.

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to show and describe what it is like for them when they are sick. Encourage them to name body parts that feel bad when they have a cold.
Sing to the tune of “The Farmer in the Dell”: “When we wash our hands, we keep the germs away. It’s how we help our friends stay well, each and every day.”.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact What a Cold Needs. Barbara Bottner wrote the book and Chris Sheban made the pictures.
Scout can’t wait to reread this book! It gives helpful information.
This week we have talked about what to do to take care of yourself when you have a cold. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: When you have a cold, what can you do to take your mind off it?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell and the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick students to participate in the prompts.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This girl has a cold. Does she look happy? What do you think she is thinking about? Show me how you look when you feel sick.
The girl likes to hear the birds outside. What do you think she’s thinking about? Can you make a peaceful resting face?
Here the girl is reading a book about faraway places. What is she thinking about? Finish this sentence: The monkey is hanging b____ (behind) the girl. Do you think the monkey is really there?
The girl played a quiet game with her dad.
The girl is feeling much better. She is smiling her silly smile.
Now we will turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: When you have a cold, what can you do to take your mind off it?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Then use Equity Sticks to choose 2–3 children to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: You can laugh at silly jokes.
You can play a board game.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about taking care of themselves and to share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What can you play when you have a cold?
I can play a quiet g_____ (game) when I have a cold.
I can play a quiet game when I have a cold.
Why is it better to think about other things when you have a cold?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Preschoolers learn new words through experiences with adults through conversation, but also through songs, stories, and word games. Provide a variety of ways for children to experience new words through multiple experiences.
